newsitem.title: BRAZIL: LatAm shrs seen firming, extending gains this week.
newsitem.headline: LatAm shrs seen firming, extending gains this week.

text.p: Stocks across Latin America were likely to firm or continue upwards this week, extending Friday's gains on strong capital flows and solid economic indicators, traders and analysts said.
They forecast continued rallies in Argentina, Brazil, Mexico and Caracas and a reversal of slides in Chile as share prices are aided by local factors and rises on Wall Street.

Brazilian stocks were seen rising on speculation regarding congressional votes on a new General Telecommunications Law and civil service reform but volatility also was expected to increase ahead of June 16 options expiry, analysts said.
"The political scenario should heat up this week and should help the market to continue to move higher," Bozano, Simonsen analysts Quentin Lewis and Robert Drummond wrote in a market report.
Sao Paulo's Bovespa index closed strongly higher Friday on hefty foreign and domestic capital flows, as local funds snapped up second-tier stocks to end the week at 11,334 points.
Traders said the bolsa should repeat the huge daily volumes of recent sessions as large capital flows to Brazilian equities continue.
Mexican stocks were seen as having upside potential to add to record gains this week on a technical breakthrough and positive fund flows to the country.
"We see the IPC gaining to 4,200 points, possibly next week, before profit-takers step in," said Francisco Blanco, research chief at the Akra brokerage.
Blanco said one potential tripwire would be fallout on the U.S. bond market from producer prices due on June 13.

The bolsa already has begun to discount the potentially adverse effects of the July 2 Federal Open Market Committee review of U.S. interest rates and July 6 congressional, state and city elections, analysts said.
Mexico's blue chip IPC index closed at a record of 4,160.85 points on Friday, a gain of 4.15 percent on the week.

Caracas shares were seen firming as positive sentiment continued to spill over from from last week's successful marginal oil field contract auction that netted Venezuela over $2 billion in bids, analysts said.
"The bulls are running and they are not likely to be stopped," wrote InvestAnalysis consultant Alex Dalmady in a market report.

The Caracas bolsa's 19-share index closed 5.7 percent higher last week at 7,244.17 points, helped by rating agency Standard and Poor's upgrade of Venezuela's long-term foreign currency debt rating to B-plus.
Chilean share prices were likely to regain composure and stabilize after last week's rollercoaster ride.

The market could be set for a small technical rise early in the week after four straight daily losses snapped a three-week bull run which pushed prices to record levels on heavy buying by foreign institutional investors, they said.
"The market will return to a more normal pace. We could see some gains in the electricals," said one broker.
The bolsa also will be awaiting news on the Telecom de Chile's long-expected merger with rival VTR. The blue-chip IPSA index ended up one percent Friday at 130.59 points.
Argentine stocks were likely to follow through on recent strong gains when trade resumes after Monday's Day of Affirmation of Sovereignty Rights over the Malvinas Islands holiday.
"Local stocks were powered by fresh foreign cash flows Friday, when U.S. long-bond yields dropped suddenly, and so they should be able to continue rising," said Adolfo Adorno of Agra brokerage.
The blue-chip MerVal index rose 3.2 percent in strong volume last week to 802.95 points, closing above 800 Friday for the first time in five years.
((-- Sao Paulo newsroom 5511 248-5413))
